overview.title: Identification, Diagnosis, Signs, Treatment, and Recommendations
overview.block1: Severe mental distress among teenagers and young adults often appears as depression, anxiety, withdrawal, low energy, and changes in sleep and appetite â€” and can even lead to suicidal thoughts. Itâ€™s important to recognize these symptoms and know how to respond, offer support, or seek professional help.
overview.block2: In recent years, especially after the COVID-19 pandemic, there has been a significant rise in emotional distress among youth in Israel. According to the World Health Organization, about 30% of adolescents report daily psychosomatic symptoms such as sadness, anxiety, and sleep difficulties. Even after October 7th, the situation has worsened, as the entire country faces emotional and economic challenges.
overview.cause1: Academic and social pressure: high expectations in school and the influence of social media.
overview.cause2: Traumatic experiences: such as security incidents, loss, or emotional abuse.
overview.cause3: Loneliness and isolation: difficulty forming meaningful social connections.
overview.help1: Listening and support: Be present and attentive â€” sometimes just being there makes a huge difference.
overview.help2: Encourage seeking professional help: Explain that reaching out is a brave and strong step.
overview.help3: Reduce stigma: Promote open conversations about mental health and reduce the shame around it.

overview.signs1: Emotional symptoms: persistent low mood, irritability, anger outbursts, emptiness, loneliness, weakness.
overview.signs2: Behavioral symptoms: withdrawal, loss of interest in hobbies, avoiding social activities, interest in death.
overview.signs3: Cognitive symptoms: difficulty concentrating, negative and pessimistic thoughts, suicidal thinking.
overview.signs4: Physical symptoms: changes in appetite and sleep.

story.title: Five Years of Pain, a Decade of Healing
story.paragraph1: A 12-year-old boy. Shy, simple. One night, something happened that changed his life forever.
story.paragraph2: There were four people who spoke to me over the phone. Everything seemed fine â€” we even became â€˜friendsâ€™. One of them was a close friend of mine. Then one day I got a message: 'Send me 5â€“10 shekels.' At first, I didnâ€™t understand and just gave my 'friend' what he asked. But one day everything turned upside down â€” those 10 shekels became hundreds, then thousands.
story.paragraph3: I received daily threats to my life. They sent me horrifying photos of dead people, saying this would happen to me if I didnâ€™t pay. They even warned that if I told anyone â€” they would shoot me.
story.paragraph4: As a small child, I was terrified and didnâ€™t know what to do. I couldnâ€™t sleep at night, I cried silently into my pillow so no one would hear. Until I lost my voice from crying too much.
story.paragraph5: Thoughts of suicide, of ending my life, fear of going outside â€” they were always in my head.
story.paragraph6: Every morning at school, as a formerly overweight kid, people mocked my body and insulted me â€” opening the bathroom door to take pictures, making me feel different, throwing words around, calling me names like 'tank'. What they didnâ€™t know was that I came to school like a â€˜corpseâ€™, after nights filled with threats and tears.
story.paragraph7: I lived for years under fear, violence, and threats. Out of fear, I gave and paid all my money so they wouldnâ€™t kill me.
story.paragraph8: I received threats to my life everywhere, at any time.
story.paragraph9: I didnâ€™t speak to anyone for years. All I wanted was to die, to make it all stop.
story.paragraph10: They told me there were cameras watching me, even in the shower â€” that they had pictures of me naked. It made me so ashamed that I showered wearing a long shirt (I was 14).
story.paragraph11: One day we had a talk. I was on the floor, exhausted, begging my â€˜friendâ€™ for help â€” to talk to them, or give me more days to pay. But then something happened I could never imagine â€” he pulled out a gun, pointed it at my head, loaded the bullets and said they would shoot me â€” while I cried in fear.
story.paragraph12: I washed my face, calmed myself, and went home as if nothing happened.
story.paragraph13: They forbade me from going on school trips or social activities, always under threats.
story.paragraph14: After five years of hell â€” he came and told me the truth: he was behind everything. Those people never existed (I was 17).
story.paragraph15: At that moment I lost trust in everyone. Something inside me broke. I said one thing: when I was little, I dreamed of being a hero â€” never a victim. I didnâ€™t hate him. The only person I hated was myself.
story.paragraph16: Over ten years of self-recovery â€” learning to accept myself and who I am. It took me 12 years to have the courage to tell my parents and friends. I paid almost 40,000 shekels in five years. I lost trust and connection with my family.
story.paragraph17: Traveling abroad helped me a lot, even became a hobby â€” but most people donâ€™t know I travel to heal myself, to escape the thoughts and pain.
story.paragraph18: After October 7th, the horrible images triggered everything again. I remembered it all and fell into a dark place. I felt alone, scared, lost â€” thereâ€™s no worse feeling than losing yourself along the way.
story.paragraph19: But I never gave up. I lost 32 kilos, served in the army, grew, and learned to love myself. Today, thank God, Iâ€™m Raad Falah from Kisra-Sumei, 24 years old, proud of who I am and the strength I found to overcome it all.
